plus round for over 2 million ended up raising three and a half million dollars to launch his company tele-border so let's check it out what's up guys welcome to another episode of founders unscripted super excited to have one of my good friends and investor in next gen t here on the show james richards he actually went from corporate just like me uh into getting the startup bug and eventually finding tele-border and we're gonna dive really deep into his story um he's gonna talk about his exit and we got some really good nuggets here super excited to have james here on the show welcome james thanks glad to have you on the show yeah appreciate it

you on the show yeah appreciate it happy to be here all right james um i'd like to just kind of dive right into kind of the back story of like you know who you are where you're from and up to the point of let's say when you got to start a bug yeah sure uh i grew up in indonesia my father is english my mother's indonesian so was there all through high school uh moved to the states for college ended up as a lawyer on wall street for a couple years uh between 2008-2010 um didn't love it felt like there was a bigger world out there and so uh i quit uh a few weeks before christmas 2010 not really having a plan or an idea as to what i was gonna go do next

came from you don't care how long that book has been on the shelf it's just a book right so long as it's the same price and and shows up at your doorstep when it should great getting legal services are the complete opposite right you have to shop for effectively the same service through multiple different providers each of whom will say that they're different in in some dimension that you aren't necessarily qualified to evaluate all the pricing is all over the place and then the timing is as well so we thought could we like make legal services more like books and make them these units that you can sell online and and buy online as consumers

takes you further away from your original idea and so um that turned out to be pretty pretty pression because what we then did was we emailed um all of the yc founders from the from the few most recent batches just cold being like hey we're in the batch um we're pivoting to this immigration thing can we help you with your business immigration needs and we actually got a lot of responses um it turns out that like serving the immigration needs of technology startups in 2013 is like this niche underserved market it's a tiny market yep but it's it's underserved high demand for talent generally price insensitive and you can

generally price insensitive and you can show them the value of getting the right people faster yep um and people weren't going after the market because they saw it as too small like the traditional incumbents and so from there we actually had customers and then once you have customers everything follows and so that was the turning point that must have been a great feeling right first cut first customer coming on board yeah about that uh it was also kind of terrifying and and kind of weird i mean like i i literally did their visa application myself which i could do because i was a lawyer but i mean i'd be i'd be lying if i said
